div.p: If you have questions about your request or are dissatisfied with the way it was handled -
First, you may contact the FOIA professional handling the request,
or the FOIA contact provided by the agency.
You may also contact the agency's FOIA Public Liaison
who is there to explain the process to you,
to assist in reducing any delays, and to help resolve any disputes.
Often, a simple discussion between you and the agency will resolve any issues that may arise.
Filing an appeal is also very simple.
Typically, all you need to do is send a letter to the appellate authority
stating that you are appealing the initial decision made on your request.
There is no fee or cost involved.
After an independent review, the appellate authority will send you a letter advising you of its decision.
Once the administrative appeal process is complete,
you also have the option to seek mediation services from the Office of Government Information Services
at the National Archives and Records Administration.
